title: How to Prepare a Pumpkin Shell for Soup

steps.headline: Place the pumpkin into a steamer large enough to hold it.
steps.description: You might need to purchase a larger steamer holder, or even use a bamboo steamer sitting over a stock pot.

steps.headline: Steam until the pumpkin starts to soften.
steps.description: You don't want to cook the pumpkin, just soften it so that it feels soft to touch on the outside.

steps.headline: Remove from the heat.
steps.description: Cut off the top of the pumpkin when cool enough to handle.

steps.headline: Remove the seeds and with a good, solid knife, carve out the flesh to about 2" or 5 centimeter (2.0 in) to the edge.
steps.description: Leave enough to maintain the shape and strength of the pumpkin shell; the edge left might depend on the type of pumpkin used.

steps.headline: Pour in the soup and serve.
steps.description: It is a good idea to place the pumpkin in a large, low bowl, in case it leaks. Place the soup ladle next alongside the soup.

text: Place the pumpkin into a steamer large enough to hold it. You might need to purchase a larger steamer holder, or even use a bamboo steamer sitting over a stock pot. Steam until the pumpkin starts to soften. You don't want to cook the pumpkin, just soften it so that it feels soft to touch on the outside. Remove from the heat. Cut off the top of the pumpkin when cool enough to handle. Remove the seeds and with a good, solid knife, carve out the flesh to about 2" or 5 centimeter (2.0 in) to the edge. Leave enough to maintain the shape and strength of the pumpkin shell; the edge left might depend on the type of pumpkin used. Pour in the soup and serve. It is a good idea to place the pumpkin in a large, low bowl, in case it leaks. Place the soup ladle next alongside the soup.
